text: Just curious if anyone uses FTP to develop locally? and what your setup look like, like what FTP client. and do you also use the HubL sever? Want to try working locally, just looking for some opinions
I use the local Hubl Server.  I only really use FTP for moving files into HubSpot for deployment.
I'm currently using Cyberduck
The main limitation I've run into is that the file structure in the local server is completely different than the file structure on HubSpot
Yeah, I see that being an issue. How do you handle that?

using prepros for styles/js works great. It has an auto ftp upload feature on save which works really well.  I've tried codekit with transmit's mount drive but it doesn't work properly on HubSpot's ftp for whatever reason.
i find this is the most efficient way to work when juggling projects. haven't really tried to a full blown local hubl environment
Basically, I just make changes to my file paths once I upload everything to HubSpot
deploying takes a little while, but nothing compared to a WP deployment

I usually store file paths in a variable.html file that I import into any files that need the paths updated (so basically there's a {{cdn}} variable that I set locally and then change one time when it's on the file manager)
this same principle can apply to anything that relies on performing request.<variable> logic
or anything relying on an array (blog content, lists of ids, etc)
ah true, thats smart
Do you guys develop templates as coded files mostly?
Mostly, far more freedom / control over the way elements are wrapped and styled and it's easier to find / access elements
The advantage for me using the drag-n-drop builder is that custom modules you've created become far easier to "drop" into place in new templates
but once something is mostly complete, I'd just export it to a coded file assuming there aren't going to be major changes to structure later on

I exclusively build coded templates.  I rely on Flexible Columns for adding custom modules when they're called for, but for most of the use cases I've used Custom Modules for in the past, HubDB does a better job
cool, thanks!

At my company we mostly develop drag n drop templates - and use coded templates just to add functionality that can’t be done in a drag n drop template (like turning a blog into a json feed)

The reason is that we work with some large companies that  often want to atleast have the ability to take care of some tasks themselves without needing someone with html/css/js skills.

For example say a client wants to edit their copyright text in their footer, they shouldn’t have to edit code to do it.

So yes, adds a small amount of development overhead but we’ve found our clients to be very happy with the level of control it gives them.

We’ve also found it has actually sped up our development time, because we’re used to the way HS structures certain things, we have our own framework we use for HS sites that we build all of our sites on and it makes it super easy to hop between client sites and not have to go “how was this done?” “where do I find the code that does this?”

another little side perk of doing this - almost every custom module we build is re-usable for other sites and layouts. 

For example - say a client has a timeline module 


and another client wants almost the exact same type of functionality. Instead of copying and pasting bits of the code and having to make the module work with the new site’s structure. We litterally just clone the custom module to a new portal - all of the site specific styling(colors fonts, line styling etc.) is not stored in the custom module, just base styling is. So all we need to do is set the new colors and differences for the new client and we’re done. Makes something like this take 5-10 minutes instead of an hour.

You can get this same level of re-usability with a coded template if you keep your framework consistent, but it’s a little harder as you have to make sure you keep certain things consistent that HS isn’t doing for you right off the bat.
Couldn't you just make the copyright footer text a {% tag %} and have it exposed to the end user that way? No need for it to be in a drag-n-drop to be end-user editable

well the downside to that is then your footer is editable on every page in the page editor.

You can still make it global, but then you get rid of the separation of what is at the page level and what is at the site level, causing clients to do unintended things like change the whole copyright to show some legalese disclaimer text, just because they wanted that text in the footer of one page (based on a real thing that happened but different set up was used)
Fair point, lol I guess I put too much trust in client marketing teams to not blow things up

<-- no faith in humans to not do something dumb when it’s made easy to do so :red_circle:

I try to avoid giving clients big red buttons, but still give them a way to change things.
Honestly, I have noticed that our client hardly ever touch the templates. They just want to be able to edit the page and pull stuff in there.

The changes HubSpot has made with the cms is really good so i am not sold on 100% coded templates for every client but you sure have a lot of flex ability in the semantics and accessibility department.
agreed
I’m still a bit boggled why the header  and footer sections aren’t header and footer elements, nor is the main section of the page a <main> and that menus are not in <nav>’s

I’d even be okay with that if they did it as a “all future sites are now this way” kinda thing and did have to update their styles.
